title-group.article-title: The diagnostic value and clinical relevance of salivary gland ultrasound in patients with highly suspected Sjögren’s Disease: a prospective monocentric study

sec.title: Objectives
sec.p: To evaluate the diagnostic accuracy of salivary gland ultrasound (SGUS) in patients with high suspicion of Sjögren’s Disease (SjD) and to determine its potential role in the diagnostic process.

sec.title: Methods
sec.p: This study is a cross-sectional diagnostic trial based on a prospective cohort, including 171 patients with high suspicion of SjD. SGUS of the parotid glands (PG) and submandibular glands (SMG) was performed according to the OMERACT scoring system. The predictive value of SGUS for diagnostic outcomes and labial salivary gland biopsy (LSGB) results was analyzed. The correlation between SGUS grading and unstimulated salivary flow rates (USFR) was also assessed using statistical tests.

sec.title: Results
sec.p: Of the 171 participants, 130 were diagnosed with SjD. The OMERACT total score demonstrated moderate efficacy in diagnosing SjD, with an area under the curve (AUC) of 0.78, a sensitivity of 0.52, and a specificity of 0.93. In comparison, LSGB showed the highest diagnostic efficacy (AUC = 0.90), followed by anti-Ro/SSA antibodies (AUC = 0.79). Combining the OMERACT total score with either anti-SSA antibodies or LSGB significantly improved diagnostic performance, achieving a specificity of 1.00. The diagnostic accuracy of parotid gland (PG) and submandibular gland (SMG) ultrasound grading was comparable. However, SMG grading exhibited higher sensitivity but lower specificity than PG grading. Additionally, SGUS grade 3 strongly predicted positive biopsy results (AUC = 0.77) and showed a significant correlation with USFR, with Spearman correlation coefficients of -0.45 for PG and -0.51 for SMG.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: Although the discriminatory efficacy of SGUS in patients highly suspected of SjD is suboptimal, SGUS may offer significant benefits for a specific subgroup of these patients. Grade 3 ultrasound findings are strongly associated with positive biopsy results and USFR, indicating a potential role in diagnosis and disease evaluation. SGUS may be considered for inclusion in future SjD classification criteria.

sec.title: Background
sec.p: The diagnosis of Sjögren’s Disease (SjD) poses significant challenges due to its complex and multifaceted pathogenesis and wide-ranging clinical manifestations. The 2002 American-European Consensus Group criteria and the 2016 American College of Rheumatology (ACR) - European League Against Rheumatism (EULAR) criteria are currently the most widely adopted diagnostic standards [1, 2]. These criteria mandate the presence of specific clinical symptoms (such as oral or ocular manifestations) supported by immunological evidence, typically confirmed via labial salivary gland biopsy (LSGB) or detection of anti-Ro/SSA antibodies. Although LSGB serves as a critical diagnostic tool, its invasive nature may result in adverse effects, including local pain, bleeding, nerve damage, permanent sensory loss, or infection [3–5], leading to reluctance among many patients in clinical settings. Furthermore, studies indicate that LSGB findings may lack consistency across repeated assessments, with approximately 50% of patients showing altered results upon secondary biopsy [6, 7]. In contrast, salivary gland ultrasound (SGUS), a non-invasive, convenient, and repeatable diagnostic modality, has garnered increasing attention from clinicians and researchers for its ability to evaluate salivary gland structure and function. By identifying abnormal morphological features, SGUS can complement LSGB and potentially enhance diagnostic accuracy.

Although several prior studies have demonstrated the high sensitivity and specificity of ultrasound in the diagnosis of SjD [8], the lack of a consistent definition for salivary gland abnormalities remains a significant challenge [9]. To address this issue, the Outcome Measures in Rheumatology Clinical Trials (OMERACT) working group developed a 4-grade semi-quantitative ultrasound scoring system aimed at enhancing both the accuracy and standardization of ultrasound assessments [10]. Subsequent studies have validated the effectiveness of this scoring system in clinical practice [11, 12].

Despite existing research, prospective studies in this field remain limited. Moreover, the diagnostic performance of tests can vary depending on the population in which they are applied. With the use of the OMERACT scoring system, the efficacy of SGUS in differentially diagnosing SjD has been further improved. However, part of its high efficacy may be attributed to previous studies that compared typical patients with a broad, less specific population. To address this gap, the present study focused on a cohort highly suspected of having SjD, evaluating the diagnostic accuracy of SGUS in this context and its predictive value for biopsy outcomes. These findings may enhance a more comprehensive understanding of the role of SGUS in the diagnosis and assessment of SjD.

sec.title: Study design
sec.p: This is a cross-sectional diagnostic trial based on a prospective cohort. All patients had not been diagnosed with SjD prior to inclusion. The study aimed to assess the diagnostic efficacy of parotid and submandibular gland ultrasound in a population with a high suspicion of SjD. The study has been registered with the Chinese Clinical Trial Registry (ChiCTR) under the registration number ChiCTR2400088752. Informed consent was obtained from all participants.

sec.title: Patients
sec.p: The patients were from outpatients and inpatients of Department of Rheumatology and Immunology, Yueyang Hospital of Integrated Traditional Chinese and Western Medicine, Shanghai University of Traditional Chinese Medicine. Enrollment occurred between March 2023 and February 2024. Inclusion Criteria: Eligible patients must undergo a clinical evaluation prior to enrollment to confirm a high suspicion of SjD. Patients should meet at least one of the following criteria for inclusion: (1) The patient fulfilled two or more items from the 2016 classification criteria, but no evidence of specific antibodies or LSGB was obtained. (2) The patient fulfilled one item from the 2016 classification criteria, and had evidence of immunological abnormalities (e.g., ANA positive, abnormal immunoglobulin), but had not yet obtained evidence of specific antibodies and LSGB. After enrollment, eligible patients will undergo the following standardized diagnostic workflow: (1) SGUS Examination: ultrasound examination of the parotid and submandibular glands using the OMERACT scoring system to detect abnormal morphology early. (2) Anti-SSA Antibody Testing: To assess immunological status. (3) LSGB Recommendation: Recommendation for LSGB for diagnostic confirmation, performed only after all prior assessments are completed. All data, including clinical evaluations, SGUS results, antibody tests, and LSGB outcomes, are prospectively collected and recorded prior to final diagnosis, ensuring the study’s prospective design. In this study, a diagnosis of SjD was made if patients met the 2016 classification criteria. All medical records were thoroughly reviewed to ensure compliance with these diagnostic standards. The exclusion criteria included: (1) Age younger than 18 or older than 75. (2) Other rheumatic immune diseases. (3) Patients with active or recent episodes of acute sialadenitis (within the past 6 months), salivary gland tumors, and other salivary gland diseases that can cause abnormal changes in SGUS, were excluded to avoid the potential impact of acute inflammation on SGUS findings. (Patients with a remote history of sialadenitis were included if they had no current symptoms or signs of inflammation). (4) Patients met the exclusion criteria outlined in the 2016 ACR/EULAR classification criteria. (5) Serious pathological changes or disabilities of important organs caused by other reasons. (6) Diabetes and malignant tumor. (7) Treated with hormones and immunosuppressants in the past. The study’s flowchart is depicted in Fig. 1.

The sample size was calculated by PASS 15.0. According to the results of previous meta-analysis, sensitivity was 0.71 and specificity was 0.78 [8]. With a statistical power of 0.99, an α level of 0.025, and an estimated prevalence of 0.7, a total sample size of 170 participants was required, including a minimum of 119 patients.

sec.title: Salivary gland ultrasound
sec.p: All ultrasound examinations were conducted by an expert sonographer with over 15 years of experience. The ultrasound equipment used was a LOGIC E20 (GE Healthcare, Milwaukee, WI, USA) with a probe frequency range of 8.0–13.0 MHz. Ultrasound images were evaluated and scored independently by an ultrasound specialist and a rheumatologist according to the OMERACT grading criteria [10]. Specific criteria are as follows: (1) Grade 0, normal parenchyma. (2) Grade 1, minimal change: mild inhomogeneity without anechoic/hypoechoic areas. (3) Grade 2, moderate change: moderate inhomogeneity with focal anechoic/hypoechoic areas. (4) Grade 3, severe change: diffuse inhomogeneity with anechoic/hypoechoic areas occupying the entire gland surface. Fatty echostructures were graded 1 (minimal change) and fibrous echostructures were graded 3 (severe change). The raters were blinded to clinical data and each other’s evaluations. In cases of discrepancy between the raters, the images were discussed, and a consensus was reached. Inter-rater reliability was assessed using Cohen’s Kappa test.

The ultrasound evaluations of the patient’s parotid gland (PG) and submandibular gland (SMG) were conducted simultaneously. Both the PG and SMG were assessed based on their bilateral ultrasound findings. For each gland, the length and area of the largest anechoic region on both sides were measured and recorded separately. The larger data of both PG and SMG ultrasound were extracted to form a new dataset named MAX.

sec.title: Labial salivary gland biopsy
sec.p: The decision of whether to take LSGB was based on patients, but patients without a LSGB were not included in the final analysis. The biopsy specimens were evaluated by pathologists, with the results interpreted according to the 2002 or 2016 classification criteria, which define a positive result as the presence of at least one focus containing 50 or more lymphocytes within a 4 mm² area of tissue. In addition to noting whether the biopsy result was positive, the focus score was also recorded.

sec.title: Unstimulated salivary flow rate
sec.p: The volume of unstimulated saliva secreted by patients over a specified period of time was measured. The test time is arranged at the same time, usually from 2 pm to 4 pm, and patients are required to fast for 1 h before the test. Prior to the test, patients were instructed to remain seated and at rest for 10 min. They then collected all saliva produced over a 15-minute period in a clean container, after which the total volume was measured. Standard definitions exist for salivary gland dysfunction: normal flow (> 0.2 mL/min), salivary gland hypofunction (0.1–0.2 mL/min), and hyposalivation (< 0.1 mL/min) [13].

sec.title: Statistical analysis
sec.p: Sensitivity and specificity were the primary evaluation metrics in this study. Group differences in qualitative data were assessed using the Kruskal-Wallis test and the Mann-Whitney U test. Correlations were analyzed using the Spearman correlation test, as well as univariate and multivariate regression analyses. A logistic regression model was used, and receiver operating characteristic (ROC) curves were generated to evaluate the efficacy of items for diagnosing SjD, as demonstrated by the area under the curve (AUC) and 95% confidence interval (CI). All statistical analyses were performed using SPSS Statistics version 26.0.

sec.title: Patients’ characteristics
sec.p: Based on the sample size calculation, a total of 171 patients were enrolled in this study. Among them, 130 were diagnosed with SjD, while 41 were excluded from the SjD diagnosis. Of the 130 SjD patients, 116 exhibited positive LSGB, whereas 14 showed negative results. The clinical characteristics of the 171 patients analyzed were summarized in Supplementary Table 1. Notably, in certain patients, SMG ultrasound demonstrated a higher degree of lesions compared to PG, but the reverse pattern was not observed. Among the 38 patients with PG ultrasound grade 1, 16 had SMG grade 1, 20 had grade 2, and 2 had grade 3. Among the 97 patients with PG grade 2, 62 also had SMG grade 2, while 35 exhibited SMG grade 3. Figure 2 showed the typical ultrasound findings for each grade. This discrepancy may be attributed to the fact that pathological changes in the SMG tend to occur earlier than in the PG, leading to some patients exhibiting a lower PG grade than SMG grade [14].

sec.title: Diagnostic efficiency of salivary gland ultrasound
sec.p: The inter-reader reliability between the two raters was first assessed. The κ for the PG ultrasound grading was 0.95 (P < 0.001), while that for SMG ultrasound grading was 0.82 (P < 0.001), indicating a high level of agreement between the raters.

sec.title: Overall diagnostic performance
sec.p: In this study, the total OMERACT score demonstrated moderate diagnostic efficacy in diagnosing SjD. ROC analysis revealed that with a cutoff value of 9, the AUC was 0.78, with a sensitivity of 0.52 and a specificity of 0.93. Among the diagnostic methods evaluated, the LSGB exhibited the highest efficacy (AUC = 0.90), followed by anti-SSA/Ro antibodies (AUC = 0.79). These results suggest that the total OMERACT score offers relatively high specificity in distinguishing SjD patients from non-SjD patients. However, when compared to the high-weight items in the 2016 classification standard, the efficacy of using SGUS alone to identify SjD patients remains inferior to that of LSGB and anti-SSA/Ro antibodies. Detailed diagnostic performance data for the OMERACT total score, LSGB and anti-SSA/Ro antibodies are presented in Table 1.

sec.title: Combined performance of OMERACT with SSA and LSGB
sec.p: To further enhance diagnostic efficacy, this study evaluated the combined diagnostic performance of the total OMERACT score with anti-SSA antibodies and LSGB. The results showed that when the total OMERACT score was combined with anti-SSA antibodies, diagnostic efficacy significantly improved, achieving a sensitivity of 0.49, a specificity of 1.00, a positive predictive value (PPV) of 1.00, a negative predictive value (NPV) of 0.38, and an overall accuracy of 0.61. Similarly, when the total OMERACT score was combined with LSGB, the sensitivity was 0.49, specificity was 1.00, PPV was 1.00, NPV was 0.38, and overall accuracy was 0.61. These findings demonstrate that combining the total OMERACT score with either anti-SSA antibodies or LSGB markedly enhances specificity and positive predictive value, making it particularly suitable for clinical scenarios requiring high diagnostic specificity. This combined approach leverages the specificity strengths of the total OMERACT score, complementing the diagnostic capabilities of anti-SSA antibodies or LSGB. Detailed performance data for the combined diagnostic efficacy of the OMERACT total score with anti-SSA antibodies and LSGB are shown in Table 1.

sec.title: Isolated glandular performance
sec.p: The diagnostic accuracy of PG and SMG ultrasound grading were comparable. However, SMG grading demonstrated higher sensitivity but lower specificity than PG grading. Neither PG nor SMG ultrasound grade achieved both high sensitivity and high specificity simultaneously. Grade 2 displayed high sensitivity (0.85 for PG and 0.95 for SMG) with low specificity (0.46 for PG and 0.24 for SMG), while grade 3 exhibited high specificity (1.00 for PG and 0.90 for SMG) with poor sensitivity (0.27 for PG and 0.52 for SMG). Detailed diagnostic performance data for parotid and submandibular gland ultrasound grading are provided in Table 1.

sec.title: Correlation between ultrasound grade and labial salivary gland biopsy
sec.p: Figure 3 presents the predictive power of ultrasound grading for biopsy outcomes. Similar to disease diagnosis, no ultrasound grade demonstrated both high sensitivity and specificity in predicting LSGB results. In predicting the results of LSGB, SGUS showed excellent performance, with an AUC value of 0.77, while the anti-SSA/Ro antibody and USFR were only 0.66 and 0.65, respectively. The high specificity of grade 3 was particularly noteworthy: all patients with a PG ultrasound grade 3, and 86% of those with an SMG ultrasound grade 3, were confirmed to have positive biopsy results. This suggested that grade 3 was a strong indicator for biopsy. The results are shown in Fig. 4.

sec.title: Correlation between salivary gland ultrasound and unstimulated salivary flow rate
sec.p: The Kruskal-Wallis test revealed significant differences in USFR among patients with varying PG ultrasound grades, with the highest USFR observed in grade 1 patients and the lowest in grade 3 patients, the differences between each pair of groups were statistically significant (Fig. 5A). Similarly, significant differences in USFR were found among patients with different SMG ultrasound grades, although the comparison between grade 1 and grade 2 groups did not reach statistical significance (Fig. 5B). The Mann-Whitney U test further demonstrated that the mean ultrasound grade in patients with impaired USFR was higher than in those with normal USFR, for both PG and SMG ultrasound (Fig. 5C and D).

caption.p: Ultrasound grade and unstimulated salivary flow rate (USFR) (A) The USFR of patients with different PG ultrasound grades (B) The USFR of patients with different SMG ultrasound grades (C) The average PG ultrasound grade of patients with normal and impaired USFR (D) The average SMG ultrasound grade of patients with normal and impaired USFR. * P-value < 0.05; ** P-value < 0.01, *** P-value < 0.001; **** P-value < 0.0001

sec.p: Spearman correlation analysis demonstrated that both PG and SMG ultrasound grades were negatively correlated with patients’ USFR, with correlation coefficients of -0.45 and -0.51, respectively. Further regression analyses confirmed that PG and SMG ultrasound grades were significantly associated with impaired USFR, with regression coefficients of -0.78 (95%CI: -1.05 - -0.51) for PG ultrasound grade and − 0.85 (95%CI: -1.11 - -0.58) for SMG ultrasound grade.

sec.title: Correlation of ultrasound features with clinical outcomes
sec.p: Spearman correlation analysis revealed that both the length and area of the anechoic region were significantly associated with biopsy results and focus scores. Similar correlations were observed in the analyses involving diagnosis. The detailed results are provided in Supplementary Table 2. Additionally, Spearman correlation analysis revealed that the length and area of the anechoic regions in both PG and SMG ultrasound were significantly correlated with USFR. The “MAX” group, derived from the larger values between PG and SMG ultrasound results, also showed statistical significance. However, due to multicollinearity among these factors, multivariate regression analysis was not performed. Similarly, visual analog scale (VAS) scores for dry mouth were significantly correlated with PG and SMG ultrasound grades. Moreover, analysis of the anechoic region showed that length had a stronger correlation with VAS scores than area. Detailed data from the correlation analyses were provided in Supplementary Table 3.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: This study was designed to assess the diagnostic value of salivary gland ultrasound in patients highly suspected of Sjögren’s Disease, a cohort that mirrors the typical clinical context in which SGUS is applied. While the incremental diagnostic benefit of SGUS may appear constrained in this preselected high-risk population, we contend that the findings carry substantial clinical significance for several key reasons.

First, SGUS stands out as a non-invasive, convenient, and cost-effective diagnostic modality, offering practical utility for patients with a high suspicion of SjD but lacking a definitive diagnosis. Beyond facilitating confirmation of the condition, SGUS can, in certain instances, diminish the reliance on invasive procedures such as LSGB. This attribute is particularly valuable in resource-constrained clinical settings, where it also serves to mitigate patient discomfort associated with invasive interventions. Although LSGB remains a cornerstone of SjD diagnosis, its procedural complexity and challenges related to patient compliance underscore the appeal of SGUS as a complementary tool. Second, the prospective design of this study specifically targets patients with suspected but unconfirmed SjD, aligning closely with real-world scenarios where SGUS is most relevant. For example, our analysis revealed a strong correlation between grade 3 SGUS findings and positive LSGB results. This suggests that SGUS could function as an effective preliminary test, informing the need for subsequent invasive evaluations and thereby streamlining the diagnostic process. By addressing this specific clinical context, our study provides actionable insights for clinicians managing analogous patient groups.

Our research is based on a semi-quantitative scoring system proposed by the OMERACT Salivary Gland Ultrasound Task Force in 2019 [10]. The reliability of the OMERACT scoring system has been validated in several studies. In 2021, Stephanie Finzel et al. reported that the weighted κ for intrareader reliability ranged from 0.44 to 1 for grading in the PG and from 0.59 to 1 in the SMG. The interreader reliability κ was 0.62 (95% CI: 0.47–0.74) for PG and 0.62 (95% CI: 0.47–0.72) for SMG [15]. In 2022, Rossana Izzetti et al. assessed the reliability of the OMERACT scoring system in minor salivary gland ultra-high frequency ultrasonography using the intraclass correlation coefficient (ICC). The ICC values for grades 0 and 1 exceeded 0.9, while the values for grades 2 and 3 were 0.873 and 0.785, respectively, demonstrating strong inter-observer consistency [16]. In 2023, Nanna S. Schmidt et al. confirmed the reliability of the OMERACT scoring system and suggested that the use of an atlas could further enhance both inter-reader and intra-reader reliability. With the atlas, inter-reader reliability improved to a moderate level (mean κ = 0.52; range 0.31–0.77), while intra-reader reliability reached a good level (mean κ = 0.69; range 0.46–0.86) [17].

The applicability of the OMERACT scoring system has been evaluated in several studies. In 2021, Xia Zhang et al. conducted a multicenter study involving 246 patients with SjD, 140 control subjects with non-SjD conditions, and 27 healthy controls. The study determined that the optimal cut-off value for the left (right) PG and the left (right) SMG was 4, achieving maximal sensitivity (75.6% and 77.2%, respectively) and specificity (91.6% and 92.2%, respectively) [18]. A more recent study investigating OMERACT scores for PG and SMG ultrasound in 242 patients reported a sensitivity of 76% and specificity of 90%, with an AUC of 0.83 at a threshold score of 8 [12].

Comparing our study with previous studies, an undeniable fact is that the diagnostic performance of SGUS may vary across different application scenarios. Variations in patient selection can significantly affect the diagnostic accuracy of a test. Unlike previous studies, which often included broader populations, this study focused on patients highly suspected of having SjD—a group that more closely reflects the clinical scenarios where SGUS is applied for differential diagnosis. These patients had typically remained under suspicion of SjD despite initial evaluations at secondary hospitals or community health centers and were predominantly referred to the rheumatology department of a tertiary care hospital. Of the 171 individuals enrolled, only 41 were ultimately not diagnosed with SjD, and 50 had negative LSGB results. The prevalence of SjD in this cohort was considerably higher than in earlier studies, leading to the underrepresentation of typical normal cases, which may have contributed to the reduced specificity observed for grade 2 ultrasound findings.

Another potential factor is the significant discrepancy between the two levels in the OMERACT semi-quantitative scoring system. In this study, when grade 2 was used as the diagnostic threshold, the sensitivity was 0.85 for the PG and 0.95 for the SMG, while the specificity was only 0.46 for PG and 0.24 for SMG. However, when grade 3 was selected as the threshold, specificity markedly increased to 1.00 in PG and 0.90 in SMG, but sensitivity dropped sharply to 0.27 in PG and 0.52 in SMG. This suggested that a midpoint between grade 2 and grade 3 may yield a more optimal diagnostic performance. Currently, grade 2 is defined as moderate inhomogeneity with focal anechoic/hypoechoic areas, while grade 3 is characterized by diffuse inhomogeneity with anechoic/hypoechoic areas occupying the entire gland surface [10]. Incorporating more specific features and refining the grading criteria could enhance the diagnostic accuracy of ultrasound in complex cases.

The application of ultrasound in the diagnosis and management of SjD merits careful consideration. Despite the strong correlation between SGUS and LSGB, the prevailing consensus is that SGUS cannot serve as a complete substitute for biopsy. This limitation stems from the fact that ultrasound does not yield immunological evidence, and the focus score derived from biopsy is critically associated with patient prognosis.

Nevertheless, the inclusion of ultrasound as an optional criterion in the classification of SjD may hold critical value. Several studies have explored this possibility with encouraging results. For example, a prospective cohort study by Esther Mossel et al. demonstrated that a positive salivary gland ultrasound, in conjunction with anti-SSA/Ro antibodies, was a strong predictor for SjD classification [19]. In 2020, S. Jousse-Joulin et al. found that incorporating a salivary gland ultrasound score (non-OMERACT) of ≥ 2 increased sensitivity from 90.2 to 95.6%, with only a slight decrease in specificity (84.1% versus 82.6%) [20]. More recently, in 2022, François Robin et al. reported that adding the OMERACT ultrasound score to the 2016 ACR/EULAR classification criteria enhanced sensitivity (91.5% vs. 89.4%) while minimally reducing specificity (96.0% vs. 100%), with an AUC of 0.975 (95% CI: 0.945–1.00) [21]. Importantly, the study by Esther Mossel et al. underscored that gland biopsy, salivary flow rate, and ultrasonography are complementary diagnostic tools and should not be considered interchangeable [22].

Research has established a significant correlation between various SGUS scores and salivary flow rates. Yasemin Yalcinkaya et al. reported that elevated Milic and Hocevar ultrasound scores were associated with decreased salivary flow rate, while the homogeneity score correlated with low USFR [23]. S. Garcia-Cirera et al. further demonstrated that both USFR and stimulated salivary flow rates were significantly correlated with ultrasound scores from the De Vita (0–3), Salaffi (0–4), and OMERACT (0–3) scoring systems [24].

Our findings corroborated that ultrasound grading is closely associated with USFR, suggesting that abnormalities identified through ultrasound reflect compromised salivary gland function. This supports the integration of ultrasound grade into the classification criteria for Sjögren’s Disease.

In addition to being a possible item in the classification criteria, ultrasound grade can also provide some predictors for LSGB in clinical practice. Omar Al Tabaa et al. proposed that negative anti-SSA antibodies together with SGUS score < 2 could avoid LSGB [25]. Our findings indicated that a grade 3 for either the PG or SMG is a strong predictor of a positive biopsy result. This evidence suggests that ultrasound, as a non-invasive and convenient diagnostic modality, is suitable as a pretest for LSGB.

It must be acknowledged that the diagnosis of SjD is a multidimensional process. While this study primarily investigates the application of SGUS in diagnosing SjD, the critical role of ophthalmological involvement in disease assessment cannot be overlooked. SjD is characterized not only by xerostomia but also by keratoconjunctivitis sicca, with the latter serving as a pivotal diagnostic feature. Routine ophthalmological evaluations, including the Schirmer’s test, tear breakup time, and ocular surface staining, are widely employed to identify tear deficiency and ocular surface damage [26, 27]. These assessments have been formally recognized and integrated into existing classification criteria [1, 2]. By combining ophthalmological evaluations with serological markers and salivary gland assessments such as SGUS, a comprehensive diagnostic framework can be established, offering a more complete representation of the clinical characteristics of SjD.

A notable limitation of this study is its design as a single-center investigation, which may have resulted in a regionally biased sample. Additionally, patients often had previously undergone evaluations at secondary or community healthcare facilities but continued to be suspected of SjD. This scenario contributed to an unusually high prevalence of SjD among the study participants, potentially explaining the discrepancies between our findings and those reported in prior studies. Nevertheless, this emphasizes the significance of our research, as the characteristics of the population on which the diagnostic test is applied are paramount. This study is prospective and closely mirrors real-world applications of ultrasound, thereby minimizing the selection bias associated with specialized populations.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: This study provides a novel reference for the application of parotid gland and submandibular gland ultrasonography in patients with a high suspicion of Sjögren’s Disease. Although the discriminatory efficacy of salivary gland ultrasound in patients highly suspected of primary SjD remains less than ideal, SGUS may offer significant benefits for a specific subgroup of these patients. Notably, individuals with ultrasound findings classified as grade 3 exhibit a strong correlation between SGUS results, positive biopsy outcomes, and unstimulated salivary flow rate. This suggests that SGUS holds potential value in both diagnostic evaluation and disease monitoring for certain patients. However, due to its limited diagnostic performance in high-risk populations, SGUS should be considered a supplementary diagnostic tool rather than a complete substitute for biopsy. Looking forward, SGUS could serve as an additional diagnostic approach within future SjD classification criteria, particularly when combined with serological testing, or as a preliminary assessment prior to labial salivary gland biopsy to enhance the overall diagnostic strategy.
